div.p: RHEGIUM (anc. geog.), ſo very ancient a city as to be ſuppoſed to take its name from the violent burſt-ing of the coaſt of Italy from Sicily ; thought to have been formerly conjoined (Mela, Virgil). A city of the Bruttii, a colony of Chalcidians from Euhœa: a ſtrong barrier oppoſed to Sicily (Strabo) ; mentioned by Luke; ſurnamed Julium (Ptolemy), from afreſh ſupply of inhabitants ſent thither by Auguſtus, after driving Sextus Pompeius out of Sicily (Strabo) ; and thus was in part a colony, retaining ſtill the right of a municipium (Inſcription). The city is now called Reggio, in the Farther Calabria.
